metadata.case_name: Petitioners (partnership firm dealing in skins) v. State of Madras
metadata.case_number: Original Jurisdiction Writ Petition Nos. 201 to 203 of 1963

facts.text: Petitioners are dealers in skins, carrying on business at Shenbakkam, Vellore, North Arcot District, State of Madras. They purchase raw skins from places both within and outside the State of Madras, tan the same and sell them through their agents in Madras.

Petitioners were assessed to sales tax under Madras General Sales Tax Act 1939 and r.16(2)(ii) of the rules on turnover of hides and skins purchased untanned outside the State but tanned within the State for assessment years 1955-56, 1956-57, and 1957-58. Tax at 3 pies per rupee for 1955-56 and 1956-57; 2% for 1957-58.
Petitioners challenged validity of r.16 as contravening Art.304; contentions negatived by Sales Tax Authorities.

Petitioners filed Writ Petition No.148 of 1959 challenging assessment for 1957-58; allowed by Supreme Court on November 22, 1962 in Firm Mehtab Majid & Co. v. State of Madras holding r.16(2) invalid as discriminating against imported hides and skins.
Validity of r.16(1) challenged in Writ Petitions Nos.43 and 44 of 1963 by M.J. Jamal Mohideen Co. on March 5, 1963, contending it discriminates by taxing raw hides/skins but not tanned.

Governor of Madras promulgated Ordinance No.3 of 1963 on June 10, 1963 to remove discrimination by levying tax on purchase price of untanned hides/skins for both raw and dressed cases during April 1, 1955 to March 31, 1959.
Sales Tax Appellate Tribunal, Madras on July 12, 1963 set aside assessments for 1955-56 and 1956-57 and remanded for reassessment per Ordinance s.2(3).

Madras General Sales Tax Special Provisions Act, 1963 (Act No.11 of 1963) received assent on August 28, 1963, deemed in force from June 10, 1963. S.2(1) targets dressed hides/skins not taxed as raw, levying 2% on last purchase price in untanned condition.
Persons purchasing raw hides/skins in Madras paid 3 pies per rupee on raw and no further tax on tanned sales; petitioners pay 2% on imported untanned purchase price.
Rate on raw hides/skins raised to 2% from August 1, 1957.
Hides and skins declared essential goods under Act 52 of 1952 (April 1, 1955 to September 11, 1956), requiring President's assent per Art.286(3) pre-1956 amendment.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.2(1) of Madras General Sales Tax Special Provisions Act, 1963 violates Arts.14, 19(1)(f)(g), 31, 286(2), 301, 304 by discriminating against imported untanned hides/skins tanned and sold in State compared to local raw purchases.
Whether s.2(1) discriminates between local merchant selling locally tanned hides/skins and first seller in State of hides/skins purchased dressed outside State.
Whether tax valid post Essential Goods Act 52/1952 without President's assent for pre-1956 sales.
Whether r.16(1) became invalid upon invalidation of r.16(2) in Mehtab case, as hides/skins tanned/untanned are one commodity.
State legislative competence to enact s.2(1) retrospectively for period when Art.286(3) required assent.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.2(1) discriminates against imported untanned hides/skins: local raw purchasers paid 3 pies/rupee on raw, no further tax; importers pay 2% on untanned purchase price (higher effective rate).
Discrimination between local tanned sales and first State seller of outside-dressed hides/skins (no untanned purchase, thus not liable under s.2(1)).
No tax on pre-Sept 11,1956 sales without President's assent per Art.286(3) and Essential Goods Act 52/1952.
R.16(1) invalid post Mehtab case as tanned/untanned hides one commodity; no tax on local raw-then-tanned, but tax on imported tanned.
S.2(1) taxes inter-State sales, beyond state power.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Entry 92A List I; s.14 Central Sales Tax Act 1956

respondent_arguments.text: Dressed and raw hides/skins are commercially different commodities, allowing different tax treatment.
No discrimination: tax on first sale of dressed hides/skins in State regardless of origin; prior raw tax exempts local but basis same.
S.2(1) applies to any first seller of dressed hides/skins; not requiring seller to be untanned purchaser.
Art.286(3) pre-1956 applies only to post-Constitution laws; 1939 Act pre-dates.
S.2(1) is machinery for tax under 1939 Act s.3/5, no assent needed; Mehtab invalidates only r.16(2), severable from r.16(1).

court_reasoning.text: S.2(1) has same discriminatory effect as invalid r.16(2) in Mehtab case: exempts dressed hides/skins taxed as raw (local), taxes imported untanned-then-dressed at higher effective rate (2% vs 3 pies/rupee = ~1.19% till Aug 1,1957).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Discrimination due to rate difference despite same base (untanned purchase price).

court_reasoning.text: S.2(1) applies to any first seller of dressed hides/skins; importer of dressed need not be untanned purchaser, tax assessable by estimate if needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No exemption loophole for outside-dressed imports.

court_reasoning.text: Raw and dressed hides/skins are different commodities commercially (tanning is manufacturing process changing nature); precedents support.
court_reasoning.key_observation: R.16(1) remains valid post Mehtab; single-point tax per kind.

court_reasoning.text: State competent: retrospective law valid if current power exists; 1939 Act predates Art.286(3); post-repeal no assent needed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislative power judged at enactment time, not operative period.

court_reasoning.text: Not inter-State sale; tax on intra-State sale of imported goods.

holdings.text: S.2(1) of Act 11/1963 invalid under Art.14 as discriminatory against imported hides/skins sold dressed till Aug 1,1957; entire s.2 unenforceable.
Raw and dressed hides/skins are separate taxable commodities.
State legislature competent to enact retrospective tax provisions without President's assent post-1956.

precedents_cited.case_name: Firm Mehtab Majid & Co. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Held r.16(2) invalid for discriminating against imported untanned hides/skins tanned in State.
Tanning is manufacturing process making tanned hides different from raw.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Andhra Pradesh v. M.A. Abdul Bari & Co.
State of Travancore-Cochin v. Shanmugha Vilas Cashew Nut Factory
precedents_cited.relevance: Processing changes commodity (cashews); inter-State sale definition.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Subban & Co. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Petitioners' view on single commodity rejected.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raghbir Chand Som Chand v. Excise and Taxation Officer
precedents_cited.relevance: Ginned/unginned cotton one commodity; not analogous to hides.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Act, 1939 (Madras Act IX of 1939)
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for tax levy on hides/skins at single point; impugned rule invalidated earlier.

statutes_cited.name: Madras General Sales Tax Special Provisions Act, 1963 (Act No.11 of 1963)
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged as ultra vires; held invalid for discrimination.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Violation alleged; Art.14 discrimination upheld; others rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Goods (Declaration and Regulation of Tax on Sale or Purchase) Act, 1952 (Act 52 of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: Declared hides/skins essential; Art.286(3) assent not required retrospectively.

statutes_cited.name: Central Sales Tax Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Treats hides/skins dressed/raw as single for CST; not binding for state tax categories.

outcome.summary: Petitions allowed; s.2(1) of Act 11/1963 declared ultra vires and of no effect for discriminating against imported hides/skins; other provisions of s.2 unenforceable.
outcome.relief_granted: Declaration that s.2 ultra vires; writ of mandamus to refrain from enforcing.

key_quotes.text: The effect of sub-section (1) of s.2 of the Act is the same as was the effect of sub-rule (2) of r.16... and which was held to be invalid by this Court in Mehtab's Case.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning linking to prior precedent on discrimination.

key_quotes.text: We therefore hold that raw hides and skins and dressed hides and skins constitute different commodities of merchandise and they could therefore be treated as different goods for the purposes of the Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects single commodity argument, upholding separate taxation.

key_quotes.text: The sub-section being void in its provisions with respect to a certain initial period, we cannot change the provision... That would be re-writing the enactment.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why entire s.2(1) invalid, not severable.
